metadata.title: Williams Syndrome  Speech Therapy
anatomical location body part affected: Face, connective tissue, brain, renal, cardiovascular, and endocrine systems
description: Williams syndrome (WS) is a rare autosomal dominant disorder that affects males and females equally and is caused by deletion of part of chromosome 7, which acts like a mutation.(1)WS is caused by a loss of DNA from band 7q11.23 of chromosome 7. It is characterized by distinctive facial features, developmental delay/intellectual disability (ID) of variable degree, prenatal-onset  growth deficiency followed by postnatal growth deficiency, joint problems, and renal and cardiovascular complications and diseases(1,2)

ICD-10 codes.Q93.82: Williams syndrome (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Individuals with WS will present with any or all of the following signs and symptoms:

Physical –Cardiovascular issues -Supravalvular aortic stenosis is a common heart defect that occurs in individuals with WS(2) -75% of patients with WS experience cardiovascular disease secondary to mutations involving the elastin arteriopathy (broken and disorganized elastin fibers)(2) -Cardiac problems, commonly heart murmurs, and congenital heart disease(1) -Hypertension (high blood pressure)(1) –Facial features -Facial features that are characteristic of WS are an "elfin-like" appearance, including a wide and prominent open mouth, long and flat philtrum, upturned broad nose, microcephaly, and dental anomalies(2,3) -Prominent earlobes(1) -Stellate patterns of the iris (characteristic pattern that appears “lacy” or “radial”)(1) -Epicanthal folds (vertical skin of the upper eyelids that covers the inner corners of the eyes)(1) -Flat, low nasal bridge(1) –Connective tissue abnormality -Soft connective tissue laxity(4) -Inguinal hernias (soft tissue protrudes through a weak point or tear in the lower abdominal wall)(1)  -Bowel or bladder diverticula (small pouch in the bowel or bladder wall)(1) -Long neck/sloping shoulders(1) -Limitations in joint ROM(1) -Rectal prolapse(1) –Growth -Prenatal and postnatal growth deficiency/retardation(4) -In infants with WS, there can be difficulty feeding, gastroesophageal reflux, and prolonged colic (> 4 months) leading to failure to thrive(1) -Chronic constipation with abdominal pain in adolescents(1) –Endocrine and renal abnormalities -Hypercalcemia (elevated blood calcium level in urine)(1,2,3) -Hypercalcemia can be treated by managing dietary intake of calcium and vitamin D to achieve levels in the normal range (1,2) -Hypercalciuria (elevated urine calcium level, which can lead to renal function impairment)(4) -Early puberty(4)

Behavior and cognition –Intellectual or learning disabilities (IQ typically between 50 and 70)(3) –Deficits in visuospatial awareness and construction, impairments in drawing/copying(5) –Poor understanding and production of spatial terms/language(5) –Deficits in number memory(3) –Impulsivity(2) –ADHD(2,6) –Hyperacusis (hypersensitivity to everyday sounds)(1,6,7) -In a study conducted in the United Kingdom, researchers found a weak inverserelationship between hyperacusis and speech perception in individuals with WS: the greater the hyperacusis, the worse the speech perception(7) –Heightened positive response to music and pitch(8) –Anticipatory anxiety or fear(1,6) –Overfriendliness and poor understanding of social norms(2,6)

Speech and language –Hoarse voice (etiology of the vocal characteristics typically is unknown in WS)(1) –Overall, language skills are considered a relative strength in individuals with WS, especially compared to mental age and language skills in individuals with similar degrees of intellectual or learning disability due to other causes; however, language abilities are not normal in patients with WS(1,2,5,9) -Historically, it was believed that speech-language  abilities in patients with WS were preserved and completely intact; however, authors of research studies have increasingly found that speech-language  skills in these patients are not intact but simply strong relative to the level of impairment in other cognitive-linguistic  areas(5,9,10,11) –Language acquisition in persons with WS is delayed and sometimes atypical compared to age-matched  peers without WS(3,12) -Studies suggest an average developmental delay of 2 years(3) -The language development of individuals with WS may be not only delayed, but also disordered and atypical(13) -Children with WS often produce referential labels (i.e., verbalizations representing early,real-world  object labels) before actually understanding and recognizing referential expressive gestures (i.e., gestures representing real-world  objects). This pattern is not typical for language acquisition and suggests deficits in joint attention(6,9) -In another atypical pattern of language development, toddlers with WS frequently exhibit fast-mapping  (i.e., the ability to acquire a partial understanding of an early word’s meaning following only brief exposure) of new objects and words  prior to demonstrating exhaustive sorting (i.e., understanding a word’s meaning as well as the appropriate semantic category to which it belongs)(13) –Adults with WS have vocabularies that are often better than expected given their mental age(5,14,15) -Concrete vocabulary and phonological processing skills are relative strengths within the language domain for patients with WS(6) –Individuals with WS often have impairments of word finding -In a study of adolescents with WS conducted in Italy, researchers noted expressive semantic paraphasias (e.g., “cat” for dog)(16) -Word-finding  impairments documented in individuals with WS include delays in language processing, longer response times in naming tasks, use of fillers and iconic gestures, and semantic substitutions(17) –Appropriate syntax is often impaired in both children and adults with WS(10,15) -Significant difficulty comprehending/understanding passive sentences(15) -Impaired production of irregular morphology has been documented in patients with WS throughout adolescence and adulthood(11) –Individuals with WS are usually very friendly and gregarious; however, they can be socially awkward due to pragmatic deficits such as inappropriate requests for attention, repetitive questioning, excessive and indiscriminate flattery, difficulty taking turns in conversation, providing too little or too much information, making irrelevant comments, and reduced comprehension of nonliteral language(6,13,18,19) -In a study conducted in the United Kingdom with 19 children with WS and 20 age-matched  typically developing children, researchers asked the subjects to produce a verbal narrative for an emotionally neutral wordless picture book. Researchers found that, although both groups produced a similar number of “emotion” words (e.g., happy, angry), the children with WS produced a significantly higher number of negative emotion words than the control group.(42) Researchers suggested that because the use of positive emotion words is associated with increased peer popularity, higher frequency use of negative emotion words might contribute to difficulty establishing and maintaining friendships in children with WS(42) -Authors of a functional MRI (fMRI) case study reported that, compared to an age- and sex-matched  control subject, the amygdala (responsible for processing emotions) showed no activation in a 17-year-old  child with WS during a facial expression processing task.(41) Impaired processing of emotions and facial expressions in conversation partners might contribute to pragmatic deficits in patients with WS –Children and adolescents with WS use excessive affective prosody (i.e., nonverbal aspects of language that connote emotion such as rising pitch contour) that does not always appropriately correspond to language content or audience(13) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: History and testing measures will differ according to the specific age and educational placement of the patient. The following recommendations are a guide and should be modified to address the needs of each individual patient

causes: In more than 99% of cases, there is a microdeletion of the 7q11.23 region of chromosome 7 (referred to as theWilliams-Beuren  syndrome critical region [WBSCR])(3,4)
pathogenesis: In WS, approximately 26 genes are deleted from the long arm of chromosome 7(6)

Studies of the brains of individuals with WS have found that there is a consistent reduction in cerebral volume withpreservation of cerebellar volume(8)–Additionally, relative to the brains of typically developing controls, the volume of cerebral, gray matter surface area in thebrains of individuals with WS is preserved compared to the reduced volume of cerebral white matter(8)–In a study conducted in Switzerland, researchers compared MRIs of the brains of 10 children with WS to those of 12age-matched  healthy controls; there was relatively normal cortical thickness present in WS with a marked decrease insurface area and increase in gyrification index(20)

WS affects multiple systems of the body–The missing genetic material on chromosome 7 typically includes the elastin ( ELN) gene; this is thought to result in thevascular and connective tissue abnormalities seen in WS(3,4)
WS is a lifelong condition that is diagnosed prenatally or shortly after birth(2)
risk factors: In most instances, WS has a sporadic occurrence and is not inherited or linked to environmental causes(2)

Nevertheless, familial transmission is a risk factor, as WS can be passed from parent to child as an autosomal dominantmutation(2)–Genetic counseling is therefore recommended for high-functioning  patients with WS with respect to the risks associatedwith pregnancy(2)

overall contraindications precautions: Speech-language  pathologists (SLPs) must be aware of the cultural and linguistic backgrounds of the patient and the patient’s family, as these can affect assessment and the treatment protocol
The SLP should involve parents as well as the patient’s teachers and other therapists in the assessment and treatment process to obtain more accurate information and best results
Review medical records and available treatment information from other professionals (e.g., physical therapist [PT], occupational therapist [OT], physician, or previous SLP)

Development of an individualized family services plan (IFSP; ages 0–3) or individualized education program (IEP; school-aged)  in collaboration with the parents/caregivers and school/educational personnel for individuals with WS is essential to address potential communication and learning problems as well as possible swallowing problems in the home or school environment
The SLP must be aware of the patient’s pain and pain tolerance levels as well as attention span, anxiety level, and any other behavioral issues

contraindications precautions to examina: History and testing measures will differ according to the specific age and educational placement of the patient. The following recommendations are a guide and should be modified to address the needs of each individual patient

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -Which physicians or specialists (e.g., cardiologist, pediatrician) are involved in the patient’s care? -What is the reason for the current evaluation/treatment for speech-language intervention? -Has the diagnosis of WS been confirmed by administering the Williams syndrome chromosomal region fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) test? -What signs or symptoms typical of individuals with WS are exhibited by the patient?

course of treatment.medical management: Lifelong medical management is required for individuals with WS Beginning in infancy, a comprehensive baseline examination by the appropriate physicians is recommended Medical management might be necessary for infants with WS who have feeding difficulties, gastroesophageal reflux, or failure to thrive Health supervision during infancy should also include an exam checking for inguinal hernia, annual audiological assessment/evaluation and vision screening, management of constipation, and a screening for hypertension(1) Throughout childhood, adolescence, and adulthood, routine health maintenance examinations are recommended for patients with WS(1) Surgical repair might be necessary to treat aortic, pulmonary, or renal artery stenosis(2) Untreated supravalvular aortic stenosis can worsen over time and lead to cardiac hypertrophy, elevated left heart pressure, and heart failure(2) Symptomatic hypercalcemia can be treated by controlling/managing dietary intake of calcium and vitamin D(1,2) Patients with WS should be monitored for hypertension throughout the life span(1) Preventive dentistry is recommended for problems related to malocclusion(1) Hyperacusis can be managed with filtered inner ear protection(2)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken? It is not recommended to give multivitamins to children with WS, as supplemental vitamin D can be harmful.(1) In addition, diligent use of sunscreen is recommended in order to minimize or prevent autologous vitamin D production(1)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  A full medical workup for an individual with WS should include most or all of the following diagnostic tests completed by the patient’s physician(s)
Complete physical and neurologic examination, plotting of WS growth parameters(1)
Full clinical cardiology evaluation: 4-limb  blood pressure measurements and echocardiography(1)
Thyroid screen for newborns (according to state mandate)(1)
Feeding team evaluation/GI evaluation: screen for rectal prolapse and management to avoid constipation(1)
Ultrasonography of bladder and kidneys  baseline evaluation and maintenance examinations(1)
Renal function studies (serum urea nitrogen and creatinine levels) and urinalysis(1)
Multidisciplinary WS medical and development evaluation(1)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had speech, occupational, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful. Document whether patient has participated in or is currently participating in early intervention services or schoolbased  services

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Are there any issues (e.g., medical, attention, or visuospatial learning) that seem to exacerbate the patient’s symptoms? Are there any specific food textures that facilitate oral intake of food in young children? Does any specific person, situation, or environment increase or decrease anxiety level in the patient?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms (e.g., cardiovascular, renal, cognitive)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of physical, cognitive, behavioral, and speech/language symptoms
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, if any. Sleep disturbances are common in older children and adults with WS.(39) In a very small study conducted in Australia (18 subjects with WS and 18 control subjects), poor sleep habits in toddlers with WS appeared to have a negative effect on language development; researchers recommended further investigation of the relationship between sleep and language development in toddlers with WS(39)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other medical or psychological symptoms that the patient is experiencing that indicate the need to refer to a physician or mental health professional (e.g., anxiety or attention issues)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document pertinent information about respiratory status including use of supplemental oxygen, tracheostomy tube, and need for mechanical ventilationNonsocial anxiety and generalized anxiety disorders are common in patients with WS.(1,6,49) Prevalence of anxiety disorders is significantly higher in individuals with WS (48%) compared to the general population (estimates range from 7 to 16%) as well as compared to individuals with intellectual disability without a diagnosis of WS (12%)(49) -Other psychosocial disturbances common among patients with WS include specific phobias (e.g., loud noises, doctor/ dentists, blood/injection) as well as irritability and often overreactions to what should be minor frustrations(6) -Document symptoms of psychosocial disturbance or behavioral problems in the child as well as within the child’s family (e.g., symptoms of depression, feelings of guilt or isolation, signs of abuse or neglect) and refer family to a social worker or psychologist if necessary  -Authors of a study conducted in Brazil with 26 children with WS found that more behavior problems were associated with lower speech and language abilities. In this study, the Child Behaviour Checklist (CBCL) was used to assess for problem behaviors. Formal (Peabody Picture V ocabulary Test, Token Test) and informal (cookie-theft  picture description) were given as assessments of speech and language. Higher single-word  receptive vocabulary and narrative vocabulary scores were associated with fewer social problems, aggressive behaviors, and overall behavioral problems on the CBCL. Additionally, the presence of perseverative speech and exaggerated prosody in speech samples was associated with increased difficulty with “thought problems” as assessed by the CBCL(44)Recurrent otitis media is common in young children with WS; unilateral or bilateral mild to moderate high-frequency  hearing loss is common in school-aged  children with WS(6) -Prior to speech and language evaluation, a patient with WS should undergo comprehensive audiological testing in order to rule out or identify hearing loss, defined by a pure-tone  average above 15 dB HL(1,6) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes __ No __ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Inquire about prior history of speech, language, or swallowing disorder(s). Document if any prior speech/language or swallow testing has been completed; if it has, review past reportsComplete a developmental questionnaire on speech and language history Document any known receptive/expressive language or auditory processing deficits. Ask parent/caregiver if patient has demonstrated delays in speechlanguage  acquisition(16)
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient, family, or caregiver about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, learning disabilities, ADHD, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, and mild to moderate hearing loss(6)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs and vitamin supplements)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient or family/caregiver about other symptoms the patient is experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient work or attend school? If the patient attends school, in which type of setting is he or she placed (e.g. mainstream, special education support)? What type of support does the patient need/receive in the school or work environment? Are cognitive or spatial deficits, including impairments in drawing or copying, interfering with progress in school or ability to function at home or in a work setting? Are psychosocial behaviors limiting the patient’s opportunity to socialize with peers?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment -Document if and what type of adaptive equipment the patient is using, such as wheelchairs, hearing aids, or glasses -Determine the effect of the patient’s speech, language, and cognitive deficits on participation in school, social, and occupational activities
social and occupational history.living environment: Obtain information on the patient’s family as well as a description of their living environment. Document languages spoken in the home, at school, or in the workplace. Identify if there are barriers to age-appropriate independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.)  A combination of standardized assessment measures and ecologically valid information measures, such as play-based  observation, should be used to evaluate the speech and language skills of a patient with WS. Standardized tests are not normed on patients with WS and therefore might not always be appropriate
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Document the use of alternative or augmentative communication (AAC). Assess the patient’s ability to use current AAC or assess for appropriateness for AAC. For detailed information regarding the use of AAC devices in speech-language  therapy, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Speech and language examination (including reading) –Speech  (articulation and phonology) -Children with WS often demonstrate signs of motor-speech  disorders, such as a developmental delay in canonical babbling, reduced fine motor control and planning, and a hoarse vocal quality(6) -Assess articulation and speech intelligibility from a speech sample; note any substitutions, omissions, or distortions; use standardized testing as able -Assess non-word  (phonological memory) repetition; this can be used to assess phonological skills, which are typically a relative strength for individuals with WS(21) -Assess both affective expressive prosody (pitch changes and vocal lengthening) and comprehension of intonation and prosody; patients with WS can have difficulty producing and understanding appropriate changes in prosody and/or intonation of speech(22)For children aged 5 years and up; assessment can be used to test form and accentual function (focus) of prosody by examining the ability to discriminate between pitch patterns, imitate the speaker, alter prosody to convey different meanings, alter expressive/receptive prosodic abilities to chunk information appropriately in grammatically ambiguous sentences, and identify pictures that best convey meaning expressed by intonation(13) -For detailed information on speech sound disorders, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topicAssess receptive and expressive language skills -In a study conducted in the United Kingdom with 75 total participants (children, adolescents, and adults) with WS, researchers found that the attentional and sensory cognitive mechanisms of the brain that are associated with face and auditory language processing were abnormally organized throughout development. The researchers conducted three separate studies in which they used event-related  potentials (ERPs) to examine the patterns of face and auditory language processing of participants with WS as well as typically developing age-matched  control subjects. Regardless of age, the ERPs for tasks that required either face or auditory language/sentence processing were abnormal in the participants with WS as compared to the control subjects(40) -The following measure is an example of an instrument that can be used to assess receptive and expressive languageMeasures receptive and expressive language skills in the areas of semantics, syntax, morphology, memory and recall, and word associations in individuals aged 6–21  years(6) -Pragmatic language skills are often impaired in individuals with WS(6) -Assess social language; note pragmatic appropriateness of language. Although conversational speech in individuals with WS tends to be fluent, the content is often inappropriate for a specific social context(16) -Adults with WS often have difficulty forming friendships and romantic relationships due to poor social skills(48) -Individuals with WS have difficulty asking for clarification(23) -Individuals with WS can be verbose(24) -In a study conducted in the United Kingdom involving four children with WS, the authors analyzed a 150-utterance language sample and scored utterances as appropriate or inappropriate. Despite their verbosity, this study found that individuals with WS often omit important information in a conversational exchange(24)a scale developed for assessment of social skills of individuals with autism spectrum disorder which can be used in persons with WS. Normed for individuals ages 2.5 through adult(48)an assessment normed for individuals aged 6–18  years that measures an individual’s pragmatic language skills. The six core tests are physical setting, audience, topic, purpose (speech acts), visual gestural cues, and abstraction  -In a study conducted in the United States with 20 children and adolescents with WS, researchers compared the TOPL-2  to the Children’s Communication Checklist–Second  Edition (CCC-2)  subscales for assessing pragmatic language abilities. Researchers found that the TOPL-2  identified significantly more children as having pragmatic language impairment than did the CCC-2,  which appeared to be an over-identification.  The TOPL-2  identified all subjects in the study who were under age 8 years as having pragmatic language impairment; hence, researchers suggested that this test was more appropriate for assessing pragmatic language abilities in older children (8+)(37) -Assess receptive and expressive syntax -Receptively, individuals with WS have more difficulty comprehending passive and past tense forms of verbs(15,25,26) -Expressively, individuals with WS exhibit various grammatical errors, such as in gender agreement (“she dressed himself”), verb conjugation, and substitutions of prepositions.(16) Individuals with WS may never develop the ability to express certain complex grammatical structures/constructions (sometimes called specific grammatical development impairment)(27)Collect a language sample of at least 50 utterances in order to analyze grammatical form productionChildren with WS often have a mean delayed growth of 2 years in MLU.(3) MLU can be measured by collecting a language sample of at least 50 utterances, counting the morphemes in each individual utterance, and finding the average/mean length of utterances based on the 50 utterances collectedMeasures understanding of grammatical contrasts in individuals aged 4 years through adulthoodAssesses comprehension of active and passive sentences in children(15) -Assess receptive and expressive vocabulary(14) -Patients with WS typically have limited expressive and receptive vocabulary,as well as grammatical ability,compared to typically developing age-matched  peers.(14)Expressive vocabulary does appear to be a relative strength for individuals with WS, who have stronger expressive vocabularies compared to children with idiopathic ID(45) -Assess vocabulary with tests of categorization, similarities and differences, and semantic development/awareness(28) -Conventional methods of assessing semantics can overestimate lexico-semantic  knowledge in children with WS; using sophisticated definition tasks instead of categorization tasks in older children is a better method of assessing semantic skills in these children(29) -Conceptual and relational vocabulary is an area of significant weakness for individuals with WS(6)A receptive vocabulary assessment normed for individuals aged 2–18  years in which a patient is asked to identify the illustration that best represents the stimulus word said by the examiner(14)An assessment for individuals aged 2 years, 6 months through adulthood that tests receptive vocabulary knowledge(14)An expressive,concrete vocabulary assessment normed for individuals aged 2–18  years; the patient is asked to name the object, action, or concept pictured(14)Normed for children aged 1.5–7  (level 1) and 8–17  years (level 2); includes subtests for expressive vocabulary, word definitions, receptive vocabulary, word opposites, multiple contexts, synonyms and figurative usage, and conjunctions and transition words(14) -Abstract language/nonliteral language comprehension -Individuals with WS typically are friendly and socially engaging; however, comprehension of abstract or non-literal language, such as sarcasm, metaphor, and simile, typically is impaired(36) -In a study conducted in Australia with 26 individuals with WS as well as 26 typically developing, mentally age-matched  controls and 26 typically developing, chronologically age-matched  controls, researchers found that individuals with WS performed significantly below the level of the chronologically age-matched  controls on all measures of comprehension of non-literal  language, but not significantly differently from that of the mentally age-matched  controls(36)  -Narrative assessment is used to determine the patient’s ability to use expressive language in a context that is more complex than conversation.(30) Narrative skills require the patient to incorporate an introduction, sequenced events, and a conclusion into his or her language sample -In a research study conducted in Portugal with 12 individuals with WS (ages 9 to 32 years), researchers found that individuals with WS produced narratives that were significantly less coherent, diverse, and complex when compared to typically developing age-matched  controls (n = 10)(30)Assess vocal function, including vocal quality, loudness, pitch, and endurance; if there are specific concerns regarding voice, refer to otolaryngologist for complete workup to rule out laryngeal pathologies prior to completing a full
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Individuals with WS typically have significant deficits in planning, executive functioning, and problem-solving  skills(3) –Relative to the other cognitive abilities, verbal short-term  memory is typically better preserved in patients with WS(9) -In a study conducted in the United Kingdom with 14 subjects, researchers found that both children and adults with WS were able to successfully use both phonological and lexical semantic information in a verbal short-term memory task(9) –The Test of Auditory Processing Skills–3rd  Edition (TAPS-3)  can be used to assess forward and backward numberword discrimination,  phonological segmentation, phonological blending, numbers forward, numbers reversed, word memory, sentence memory, auditory comprehension, and auditory reasoning –Review any available cognitive assessments that have been completed; refer to psychological, neuropsychological, and cognitive evaluations for in-depth cognitive assessments if these have not already been completed

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis who have motor involvement are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

SLPs should be aware of various learning, behavioral, anxiety, and attention disabilities/issues that are associated with WS when assessing and treating their patients.(2) It might be necessary to complete the initial evaluation across multiple sessions
Patients can demonstrate behavioral problems, such as indifference to personal safety; extra caution should be taken with respect to patient and clinician safety(2)
It is important to consider an individual and family’s cultural and linguistic background during the development of therapy activities

Patients with WS, especially infants, are at increased risk for swallowing and feeding difficulties. Ensure that the patient and family/caregivers are aware of potential aspiration risks and educated about compensatory strategies when appropriate

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Patients with WS leading to speech and/or language deficits can benefit from speech therapy. Together with the patient and the patient’s family/caregiver(s), the SLP will determine if speech-language  therapy is appropriate for a given individual with WS
assessment plan of care.rule out: The patient’s physician will use DNA evaluation and Williams syndrome chromosomal region FISH test to determine size of the deletion and to confirm WS diagnosis
prognosis: In a study conducted in Australia, researchers documented cognitive improvements in 27 patients with WS (mean age of 16 years at the start of the study) over a period of 5 years; it was not possible to make an accurate prediction regarding improvements based on initial cognitive profile. Factors such as therapeutic intervention and modifications of the individual’s environment are likely to improve his or her developmental trajectory(33)
In a research study conducted in the United Kingdom, researchers found that adults with WS (up to the age of 50) did not show evidence of deteriorating cognitive or behavioral abilities over time(34)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Refer to physicians, psychologist, OT, PT, audiologist, and other professionals as appropriate
treatment summary: Involve the patient’s family in treatment as much as possible, including parental observation of and participation in therapy sessions, take-home  practice exercises, and/or regular therapist/parent conferences
Choosing therapy goals that focus on academic and social language can help patients be more successful and functional in school and social settings

Treatment approaches for specific areas of need (e.g., vocabulary, syntax, pragmatics) are determined based on the results of a thorough speech-language evaluation and the individual patient’s personality and response to trial therapy. There are no known studies examining the effects of specific speech-language  therapy treatments on the speech and language of  individuals with WS; however, the following general suggestions are based on the known strengths and weakness of these individuals: –Because the age of acquisition of 10- and 50-word  expressive vocabularies is strongly correlated with future language development, all older infants and toddlers with WS should receive speech therapy to promote the growth of expressive vocabulary(6) -Many early intervention developmental therapists use the onset of referential communicative gestures as the most promising indication that a child will benefit from speech therapy(6) –Utilizing basic sign language can be useful for initiating early communication/language in young children with WS who are delayed in the development of speech(6) –Prior to discharging an older child or adolescent from speech therapy when he or she has intelligible speech and functional language abilities, perform a detailed assessment of pragmatic skills, as these can be problematic for older individuals with WS(6) -For older children, deficits in the areas of nonliteral language and metalinguistics can have a significant impact on social skills and academic performance; assess and provide treatment as appropriate(6) -For many older children with WS, it is important to assess and treat reading deficits as appropriate; refer to reading or intellectual/learning disabilities specialist as needed(6) –For many infants and young children with WS who have failure to thrive, perform a full feeding and swallowing assessment with intervention as appropriate(6)

Social skills training: In a pilot study conducted in the United States with adults with WS, researchers found that direct training of social skills resulted in improvements on objective assessments of social skills. Researchers recommended continued research on the effects of social skills training for persons with WS(48) . improved use and comprehension of syntactical forms–Test for the Reception of Grammar, Version 2–MLU
improved swallowing ability–Repeated swallow evaluation–Weight/growth chart–Chest X-rays

Review of the goals set in the initial plan of care–For children with WS, outcome statements outlined in the IFSP or IEP should indicate the context or environment inwhich the outcomes should occur-For preschoolers, these outcomes may occur within the context of school in addition to the home setting–Consideration of future goals is always recommended when developing immediate goals

maintenance or prevention: When working with individuals with WS, it is important to continually monitor their changing needs and status. Due to changing patient needs, it is important to follow up with communication goals and intervention and change them as appropriate(6)
patient education: See patient information from the Williams Syndrome Association at https://williams-syndrome.org/
